item.title: Prominent pro-Kurdish lawyer shot dead in Turkey
item.description: Tahir Elci was killed after clashes between rebels and security forces broke out in a southeastern city.

item.title: Three killed in attack on UN base in northern Mali
item.description: Unidentified gunmen hit UN peacekeeper base with mortar fire in the northern town of Kidal, also wounding 20.

item.title: Thousands displaced by Myanmar military offensive
item.description: More than 10,000 people have fled their homes in Shan state with sexual assault reports surging, rights group says.

item.title: Japan's newest and largest mosque opens its doors
item.description: The Ahmadi Muslim community in Japan hopes its new mosque will promote intercultural understanding and dialogue.

item.title: Gunmen kill four policemen in Egypt's Giza
item.description: Masked men riding a motorbike open fire on police officers in Giza, killing four.

item.title: UN: Number of teens dying of AIDS tripled over 15 years
item.description: AIDS is leading cause of death of African children and second most common killer of adolescents globally, UNICEF says.

item.title: Through a lens: Nigerian orphans capture their country
item.description: A group of orphans and street children have been trained in photography and asked to capture the world around them.

item.title: Relative of Netanyahu says PM against Palestinian state
item.description: Amid the current tensions and violence, we speak to Palestinians and Israelis, including Netanyahu's brother-in-law.

item.title: Drowned Syrian boy's family to settle in Canada
item.description: Aunt of refugee icon Aylan Kurdi says Ottawa has approved application to bring her brother's family to Canada.

item.title: Turkey's president warns Russia not to 'play with fire'
item.description: Erdogan condemns reports that Turkish businessmen were detained in Russia as animosity between Cold War rivals grows.

item.title: Suicide attack targeting Afghan official kills guard
item.description: Election commission official escapes unharmed after attack on his vehicle in Kabul kills bodyguard.

item.title: Palestinian refugees strike against UN funding changes
item.description: In Jordan, volunteers at community organisations for Palestinians fear the funding crisis could presage bigger changes.

item.title: Analysis: Jailing reporter reflects Iran power struggle
item.description: Iranian hard-liners using arrests to wrest back power from moderate President Rouhani, pundits say.

item.title: Japan scrambles jets after Chinese military exercises
item.description: Fighter aircraft deployed by Tokyo after 11 Chinese planes spotted close to Japanese airspace during 'unusual' dispatch.

item.title: Blundering British foreign policy
item.description: The Cameron administration's policy choices abroad have their roots in Thatcher's legacy.

item.title: Oslo is dead, but what's next?
item.description: Today there is a growing sense that Israel must set the agenda for the post-Oslo era.

item.title: Gunman kills three in US abortion clinic shooting
item.description: Attacker surrenders after deadly five-hour standoff at Planned Parenthood hospital in the central United States.

item.title: Maldives police in violent crackdown against opposition
item.description: Several opposition officials hospitalised in rally calling for the release of jailed former President Mohamed Nasheed.

item.title: Five Poles abducted as pirates storm ship off Nigeria
item.description: Captain, three officers and a sailor are kidnapped, but 11 seamen escape harm by locking themselves inside the ship.

item.title: Who is buying ISIL's oil?
item.description: Turkey has been forced to deny Russian allegations that it buys oil from the armed group and says Assad is a customer.

item.title: Ten priests receive death threats in Bangladesh
item.description: Single letter lists names of priests in and around the city of Rangpur, saying that they will be killed one by one.

item.title: Israel to open office for renewable energy in Abu Dhabi
item.description: UAE says opening "does not represent any change in position" between the nations which do not have diplomatic relations.

item.title: 'The Punisher' to run for president in the Philippines
item.description: Davao Mayor Rodrigo Duterte, who has admitted links to death squads in Mindanao, shakes up the 2016 presidential race.

item.title: Ex-Afghan PM Hekmatyar calls for 'real and fair peace'
item.description: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, labelled a "global terrorist" by US, issues video from hiding place seeking inter-Afghan dialogue.

item.title: Suicide attack hits Shia procession in Nigeria
item.description: At least 10 people die after blast rocks procession of followers marching from Kano to Zaria in northwest Nigeria.
